Award.AwardTitle: REU Site for Astronomy and Astrophysics at UW-Madison: 2016 and beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin Madison will host an REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) site in astronomy. Students will work under close supervision of faculty and research scientists for ten weeks each summer on research projects that span a broad range of scientific areas. This program will benefit society by enhancing the education of undergraduates through research and professional development programs and by extending these opportunities to students from institutions otherwise unable to offer such experiences. Students will be actively recruited at meetings of several national organizations and through participation in the National Astronomy Consortium, a new partnership that focuses on the recruitment and continued professional development of underrepresented minority students.

Research opportunities include experimental physics, instrumentation, and astrophysics. All faculty mentors are required to participate in a training seminar offered at the start of each summer. The program also includes: a lecture series in astrophysics, training in scientific presentations, web-page and Python programming, scientific ethics, graduate school preparation, field trips, and opportunities to participate in public outreach events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Learning research by doing research" is the key motivation and driving force for the Research Experience for Undergraduate Program in Astrophysics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. 

Building on years of prior experiences, this project enabled 21 students to spend 10 weeks of their summer in beautiful Madison, Wisconsin, working hand-in-hand with researchers in the Department of Astronomy, Department of Physics, and at the Icecube South Pole Neutrino Observatory. Their research projects spanned a wide range of topics from all over astrophysics, from building and characterizing the next generation of state-of-the-art instrumentation, developing software and analyzing observations from telescopes across the globe and even in space, to unraveling the mysteries of black holes and the formation and evolution of galaxies across cosmic times. Towards the end of each summer all students proudly present their results in a special research symposium, attended by not only members of the Department of Astronomy, but also by a significant number of interested colleagues from across campus.

In addition to their research work, students also receive professional development training, from research ethics, how to read and write scientific literature, preparation for graduate school, to web-page design, among many others. On the social side, all summer students are integrated into their research groups including scientists at all levels, from faculty to graduate and undergraduate students, giving them a real taste of life as an astronomer. Furthermore, socializing on Madison's lakefront, mixing with fellow students from other programs, and taking part in our "Universe in the Park" outreach program not only ensure a positive work-life balance, but also make for a highly enjoyable summer for everyone involved.

Special highlights of the program are organized field-trips to nearby research facilities such as Fermilab, and in particular the participation at a scientific meeting such as the annual meeting of the American Astronomical Society. These meetings, attended by thousands of fellow scientists from across the country and worldwide. not only gives each student the opportunity to present their science to their peers, but also kick-starts their research networks and careers in physics and astronomy and beyond for years to come. At the time of writing, the majority of our participants are still actively engaged in the field, either as graduate students or in teaching roles.
